title: Live updates: Trump says he’ll decide on Iran strike within two weeks
description: The Soroka Medical Center strike caused “extensive damage,” the hospital said. Iran said it targeted military and intelligence headquarters near the hospital.
author: Lior Soroka, Frances Vinall, Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Annabelle Timsit, Sammy Westfall
byline: Lior Soroka, Frances Vinall, Niha Masih, Andrew Jeong, Abbie Cheeseman, Annabelle Timsit, Sammy Westfall, Amaya Verde, Álvaro Valiño, N. Kirkpatrick, Mikhail Klimentov, Nilo Tabrizy, Natalie Allison, Abigail Hauslohner, Mohamad El Chamaa, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Matt Viser, Mustafa Salim, Natalia Abbakumova, Paul Schemm, Washington Post staff, Ilan Ben Zion, Joshua Yang, Karen DeYoung, Ellen Francis, Alex Horton, Maham Javaid, Warren P. Strobel, Julie Yoon, Susannah George, Jintak Han, Suzan Haidamous, Kareem Fahim, Alon Rom, Michael Birnbaum
excerpt: The Soroka Medical Center strike caused “extensive damage,” the hospital said. Iran said it targeted military and intelligence headquarters near the hospital.
text: President Donald Trump will make a decision on action against Iran within the next two weeks, the White House said Thursday. “Based on the fact that there’s a substantial chance of negotiations that may or may not take place with Iran in the near future, I will make my decision whether or not to go within the next two weeks,” Trump said, according to press secretary Karoline Leavitt, who told reporters it was a direct quote from the president. Also Thursday, Israeli officials said they would intensify strikes on Tehran after an Iranian missile attack struck a key Israeli hospital. What to know as Israel and Iran trade strikes for seventh dayReturn to menuSoroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, was directly hit during a missile barrage on June 19, the hospital and the Israel Defense Forces said. (Video: The Washington Post)Israel and Iran traded fire for a seventh day Thursday.A wave of Iranian missiles penetrated Israeli air defenses and struck three buildings, Israeli police said Thursday, including the largest hospital in southern Israel. At least 45 people were wounded from shrapnel and blasts, according to Israel’s Magen David Adom emergency service; around 80 people in total were injured, the Soroka Medical Center said. Iran state media said the missiles were intended for an Israel Defense Forces technology unit and an intelligence camp about a mile from the hospital.Israel said it struck targets across Iran in the past 24 hours, including around Tehran, and several nuclear sites. Israel’s military said it hit the inactive Khondab heavy water research reactor overnight and a target near Natanz, and an Israeli military official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to brief reporters on military operations, said it also struck a nuclear-related facility in Isfahan. Other reported attacks across Iran have been difficult to immediately verify because the country has been under a near-total internet blackout since Wednesday night.British foreign secretary David Lammy met with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Steve Witkoff, Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, Thursday in Washington. On social media, Lammy said that “a window now exists within the next two weeks to achieve a diplomatic solution.”Live coverage contributors 35Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit TehranReturn to menuSince Friday, Tehran and its surrounding area have received the brunt of the strikes, according to data from the Institute for the Study of War. The explosions, which have continued for days, have struck missile and defense facilities, government buildings, oil production facilities, office buildings and an airport and university. One strike even tore through an Iranian state television studio during a live broadcast Monday.Return to menuThe Israeli military announced an evacuation order Thursday evening for Kolesh Taleshan, a small village in northern Iran. On a map accompanying the evacuation notice, the military put a red circle over the Sefidrood industrial park.Conflict in Mideast causes battle within MAGA ranks — stay out or fight? Return to menuThe prospect that President Donald Trump may order an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities has torn a rift among leaders of his political base, a coalition partly forged by Trump’s opposition to previous Middle East wars.Some of the prominent voices in Trump’s Make America Great Again movement — right-wing allies who championed even his most controversial positions and stood by him after his 2020 loss — are warning that assisting Israel against Iran would be a bridge too far.This is an excerpt from a full story.How many people have been killed and injured in Iran and Israel?Return to menuBack and forth strikes between Israel and Iran — which began with Israeli attacks June 13 — have killed scores of people in both countries.Iran’s government said Sunday that 224 people had been killed. At least 24 people in Israel have died in Iranian strikes, Israel’s government said.Return to menuHezbollah leader Naim Qassem issued a statement Thursday saying it stood with Iran against Israel and what it called “the arrogant tyrants — led by America.”“We are not neutral. Therefore, we declare our position in support of Iran, its leadership, and its people — and we will act as we see fit in confronting this treacherous American-‘Israeli’ aggression,” Qassem said in a statement sent by Hezbollah’s spokesperson. He also said President Trump’s “threat of aggression” against Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei constitutes “an attack on all the peoples of the region.”The Iranian-backed militant group has stepped up its symbolic support for Iran in the past few days, including hosting a solidarity event for Iran in Beirut tomorrow.Return to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s complaint Thursday that his son’s wedding was postponed due to a conflict that has killed dozens of Israelis is not landing well.Speaking to reporters at the Soroka Medical Center, struck Thursday by Iran, Netanyahu compared the “people’s resilience” of Israelis to that of the British during the Blitz, the Nazi German bombing campaign against British cities during World War II. “We are going through a Blitz,” he said. And he said his “own family has not been spared,” he added.“This is the second time my son, Avner, has had to cancel his wedding due to rocket fire and the threat of missiles,” he said. “That is certainly a heavy personal cost for him, for his fiancée, and for our family.“What are dead and wounded people, and those who lost everything to the missiles, compared to the personal price of the Netanyahu family?” wrote journalist Aviad Glickman of Israel’s Channel 13 on X.Return to menuThe Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, faced a barrage of missiles from Iran on June 19. (Video: Heidi Levine for The Washington Post)More than 700 patients were at the Soroka Medical Center when the strike hit Thursday, the facility said. Some 80 people, half of them staff, suffered injuries it called “mild or stress-related.”Scores of patients have been discharged or transferred to other hospitals. Around 300 patients remain.The hospital is now closed to non-urgent admissions.Trump to make decision on Iran strike within two weeks, White House saysReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump says he will make a decision about whether to take action in Iran within the next two weeks, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Thursday.In what she called a “message directly” from Trump, Leavitt told reporters: “And I quote, ‘Based on the fact that there’s a substantial chance of negotiations that may or may not take place with Iran in the near future, I will make my decision whether or not to go within the next two weeks.’”Israel claims Iran launched cluster munitionReturn to menuIsrael’s Home Front Command alleged Thursday that Iran had launched a missile equipped with a cluster warhead toward central Israel.Cluster munitions disperse bomblets across a wider area than a single missile strike, to increase damage. They’re typically deployed against troops, vehicle convoys and airfields.Some lethal bomblets can settle on the ground without detonating, posing an ongoing danger to civilians as well as military personnel.Return to menuPrime Minister Netanyahu on Thursday visited the Soroka Hospital, which was hit in an Iranian strike. He posted a video on X with the health minister and mayor of Be’er-Sheva. “We are hitting with precision the targets of the nuclear and missile programs, and they’re hitting a hospital,” he said.Trump is as unpredictable as ever, even when faced with war Return to menuDoes he want to be a wartime president, or the broker of peace? Can he convince his MAGA base that going to war with Iran isn’t the kind of entanglement he has spent more than a decade warning against?Even he doesn’t seem to know yet. “You don’t seriously think I’m going to answer that question?” President Donald Trump said when asked Wednesday if he had decided on U.S. strikes in Iran. “... You know, I may do it. I may not do it.”This is an excerpt from a full story.State Dept. considering ‘all available options’ for U.S. nationals in IsraelReturn to menuThe State Department said it is considering “all available options” to repatriate U.S. nationals stuck in Israel as the country’s conflict with Iran intensifies and its airports and seaports remain restricted.The department said in a statement that it “is always planning for contingencies to assist with private U.S. citizens’ departure from crisis areas” and will provide more information as options become available. It recommended that U.S. nationals take any available safe route out of Israel.Return to menuGrand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, Iraq’s top Shiite authority, warned in a statement Thursday that targeting Iran’s senior religious or political leadership would have “extremely grave consequences for the situation across the entire region,” in an apparent reference to President Donald Trump saying that he would not assassinate Iran’s supreme leader — for now. “It may lead to complete loss of control and widespread chaos, further worsen the suffering of people and severely harm the interests of all parties involved,” he said. Following an Iranian strike that hit a hospital in southern Israel on Thursday, Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, “can no longer be allowed to exist.”Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit IranReturn to menuAirstrikes continued for a seventh day Thursday amid the most intense faceoff in the history of the Israel-Iran conflict. Israel said it struck targets across Iran in the past 24 hours, including around the capital, Tehran, and several nuclear sites. Israeli officials said they would intensify strikes on Tehran after a key hospital in southern Israel was hit in an Iranian missile attack.This is an excerpt from a full story.Russia warns Israel against hitting Iran’s nuclear facilitiesReturn to menuRussia’s Foreign Ministry issued a stern warning to Israel against raids on Iran’s nuclear facilities amid mistaken reports that the country’s only functioning nuclear plant was attacked.The Bushehr nuclear power plant on the Persian Gulf is partly operated by Russian technicians. After a news report Thursday cited Israel as saying the site was attacked, an Israeli military official later told reporters at a briefing that “it was a mistake” to include Bushehr in the list of sites attacked.We asked 1,000 Americans if they support U.S. strikes on Iran. This is what they said.Return to menu (Video: The Washington Post)What do Americans think about the possibility of launching U.S. airstrikes against Iran, which President Donald Trump threatened this week unless the country dismantles its nuclear program? The Washington Post texted more than 1,000 people on Wednesday to ask.The poll finds Americans opposing U.S. airstrikes against Iran by a 20 percentage-point margin — 45 percent to 25 percent — with a sizable 30 percent saying they are unsure.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuThe Israeli military estimates it has destroyed two-thirds of Iran’s missile launchers over the first seven days of the conflict, according to a military official speaking on the condition of anonymity to brief reporters on military operations. Israel estimates there to be “more than 100” launchers left in Iran’s arsenal, the official said, without citing evidence for the estimate, which could not be independently verified.Soroka Hospital is among largest in IsraelReturn to menuSoroka Medical Center, which was hit Thursday during an Iranian missile barrage, is among the largest hospitals in Israel.The scene at Soroka Medical Center, hit in strikeReturn to menuReporting from Soroka Medical CenterBEER SHEVA, Israel — Israel’s Soroka Medical Center was hit in an Iranian attack, the medical center and Israeli officials said Thursday, which caused a fire to break out and damage across the hospital.Israeli military engineers were assessing the extent of the damage to one of the country’s largest hospital facilities, which evacuated patients following the attack. “We’ve closed the medical center except for emergency care,” Shlomi Codish, the hospital’s director, told reporters.These Iran nuclear sites are in Israel’s crosshairs as U.S. weighs strikes Return to menuPreventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons has been the primary goal of U.S. and Israeli policy toward Iran for decades. The Iranian nuclear program has existed in some form since the 1950s, when Iran was ruled by a U.S.-backed monarchy and Washington supported the development of an Iranian civil nuclear sector. On Friday, Israel launched a wave of strikes on Iran, including on its nuclear facilities. As the United States weighs whether to join Israeli efforts to take out Iran’s nuclear program, here’s what we know about the sites that Israel has attacked so far, why they are so difficult to destroy and what nuclear hazards the strikes could pose.This is an excerpt from a full story.European foreign ministers plan to meet with Iranian counterpart Friday, officials sayReturn to menuBRUSSELS — European foreign ministers will hold talks with their Iranian counterpart on Friday in Geneva, a meeting being coordinated with Washington, two officials familiar with the planning said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive plans.Foreign ministers of Germany, France and Britain will meet with E.U. foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas and then hold talks with Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, the officials said.What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb? Return to menuIn the event the United States enters the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran, a likely focus will be on degrading or destroying Tehran’s underground facilities that enrich nuclear material.That task would most likely fall to a small number of Air Force strategic bombers that are capable of delivering 30,000-pound precision-guided bombs designed to destroy subterranean targets. This bomb, the GBU-57, is better known as a “bunker buster” or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator.This is an excerpt from a full story.Video: Israeli rescue workers inspect missile strike site in Ramat Gan Return to menuRescue workers and military personnel inspect the site of a direct hit from an Iranian missile strike in Ramat Gan, Israel, on June 19. (Video: Reuters)Putin and Xi say Israeli attacks violate international lawReturn to menuRussian President Vladimir Putin spoke with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, about the situation in the Middle East and condemned Israeli attacks on Iran, a top Russian official said Thursday. Return to menuClosing the Strait of Hormuz is one option Iran is considering, Behnam Saeedi, a member of Iran’s parliamentary National Security committee, told the semiofficial Mehr news agency Thursday. Some 20 percent of oil traded globally passes through the strait, which connects the Persian Gulf with the Gulf of Oman and Arabian Sea.U.N. nuclear watchdog says no radiological effect after Khondab strikeReturn to menuBEIRUT — The United Nations nuclear watchdog said Thursday there were no radiological effects after Iran’s Khondab heavy water research reactor was hit.The Israeli military said its warplanes hit the inactive nuclear reactor in Arak overnight and targeted its “component intended for plutonium production, in order to prevent the reactor from being restored and used for nuclear weapons development.”Near-total internet blackout in Iran, NetBlocks saysReturn to menuIran’s near-total internet blackout extended beyond 20 hours on Thursday, according to NetBlocks, which monitors internet access worldwide.The disruption began Wednesday evening, and internet traffic monitoring into the afternoon Thursday showed “no sign of restoration,” NetBlocks said in a statement.Return to menuRussian President Vladimir Putin said he is in contact with Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu about the conflict between Israel and Iran and called for a solution that protects the interests of both sides. Speaking to journalists Wednesday at the Saint Petersburg Economic Forum, Putin acknowledged it was a “delicate issue” but said he believes “such a solution can be found.”Photos: Iran strikes Ramat Gan, a business district near Tel AvivReturn to menuPhotos from Ramat Gan, a business district in the Tel Aviv area, show a heavily damaged residential building on Thursday morning after the latest round of missile strikes from Iran.With ally Iran under attack, Hezbollah stays out of the fray for now Return to menuBEIRUT — Hezbollah is holding its fire during Iran’s conflict with Israel as it faces domestic pressure not to drag a fragile Lebanon into war and bets the violence does not yet threaten the survival of its longtime patron, diplomats and people close to the group said.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuVideo verified by The Post shows plumes of smoke rising over Ramat Gan, Israel, on June 19, as the conflict between Iran and Israel enters its seventh day. (Video: X)Ramat Gan, a city near Tel Aviv in Israel’s Dan area, was hit in a missile strike, mayor Carmel Shama-Hacohen said on Facebook. The strike hit an area with residential and commercial buildings, marking the third time in the current conflict with Iran that the city was affected, he said. Visuals showed an apartment building was hit.Return to menuPrime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday morning on X that Israel will “exact the full price” from Iran for its missile attack that hit the Soroka Medical Center in southern Israel.Hospital in southern Israel hit during missile barrageReturn to menuSoroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, was directly hit during a missile barrage on June 19, the hospital and the Israel Defense Forces said. (Video: The Washington Post)Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, was directly hit during a missile barrage early Thursday, the hospital and the Israel Defense Forces said. A spokesperson for the hospital said on X that there was “extensive damage” and that it was carrying out an assessment, including of casualties.Israel’s Fire and Rescue Authority said a direct hit on the medical facility caused a fire. The hospital is the largest in southern Israel, according to the Israel Defense Forces.Return to menuDefense Minister Israel Katz said Wednesday in a statement that he has instructed the Israeli military to “intensify strikes against strategic targets in Iran and government sites in Tehran,” in retaliation for the hospital attack. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, will be held accountable for the attack, Katz added. President Donald Trump said this week he knows Khamenei’s location but is not looking to assassinate him for now.Trump gave Iran an ultimatum but has made no final decision on war Return to menuPresident Donald Trump told reporters on June 18 he hasn’t decided whether to strike Iran’s nuclear facilities. (Video: The Washington Post, Photo: Tom Brenner/The Washington Post)President Donald Trump delivered an “ultimate ultimatum” to Iranian leaders to dismantle their nuclear program, he told reporters on Wednesday. But he said he has not made a final decision about whether to strike Iran and draw Washington into a new conflict in the Middle East.Trump said “the next week is going to be big” and maintained that Iranian officials are eager to negotiate, but he explained that after Iranians reached out to him, he warned them that “it’s very late to be talking.”This is an excerpt from a full story.
html:
President Donald Trump will make a decision on action against Iran within the next two weeks, the White House said Thursday. “Based on the fact that there’s a substantial chance of negotiations that may or may not take place with Iran in the near future, I will make my decision whether or not to go within the next two weeks,” Trump said, according to press secretary Karoline Leavitt, who told reporters it was a direct quote from the president. Also Thursday, Israeli officials said they would intensify strikes on Tehran after an Iranian missile attack struck a key Israeli hospital.

What to know as Israel and Iran trade strikes for seventh day

Return to menu

  • Israel and Iran traded fire for a seventh day Thursday.
  • A wave of Iranian missiles penetrated Israeli air defenses and struck three buildings, Israeli police said Thursday, including the largest hospital in southern Israel. At least 45 people were wounded from shrapnel and blasts, according to Israel’s Magen David Adom emergency service; around 80 people in total were injured, the Soroka Medical Center said. Iran state media said the missiles were intended for an Israel Defense Forces technology unit and an intelligence camp about a mile from the hospital.
  • Israel said it struck targets across Iran in the past 24 hours, including around Tehran, and several nuclear sites. Israel’s military said it hit the inactive Khondab heavy water research reactor overnight and a target near Natanz, and an Israeli military official, speaking on the condition of anonymity to brief reporters on military operations, said it also struck a nuclear-related facility in Isfahan. Other reported attacks across Iran have been difficult to immediately verify because the country has been under a near-total internet blackout since Wednesday night.
  • British foreign secretary David Lammy met with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Steve Witkoff, Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, Thursday in Washington. On social media, Lammy said that “a window now exists within the next two weeks to achieve a diplomatic solution.”

Live coverage contributors 35

  • Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit Tehran

    Return to menu

    Since Friday, Tehran and its surrounding area have received the brunt of the strikes, according to data from the Institute for the Study of War. The explosions, which have continued for days, have struck missile and defense facilities, government buildings, oil production facilities, office buildings and an airport and university. One strike even tore through an Iranian state television studio during a live broadcast Monday.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military announced an evacuation order Thursday evening for Kolesh Taleshan, a small village in northern Iran. On a map accompanying the evacuation notice, the military put a red circle over the Sefidrood industrial park.

  • Conflict in Mideast causes battle within MAGA ranks — stay out or fight?

    Return to menu

    The prospect that President Donald Trump may order an attack on Iran’s nuclear facilities has torn a rift among leaders of his political base, a coalition partly forged by Trump’s opposition to previous Middle East wars.

    Some of the prominent voices in Trump’s Make America Great Again movement — right-wing allies who championed even his most controversial positions and stood by him after his 2020 loss — are warning that assisting Israel against Iran would be a bridge too far.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • How many people have been killed and injured in Iran and Israel?

    Return to menu

    Back and forth strikes between Israel and Iran — which began with Israeli attacks June 13 — have killed scores of people in both countries.

    Iran’s government said Sunday that 224 people had been killed. At least 24 people in Israel have died in Iranian strikes, Israel’s government said.

  • Return to menu

    Hezbollah leader Naim Qassem issued a statement Thursday saying it stood with Iran against Israel and what it called “the arrogant tyrants — led by America.”

    “We are not neutral. Therefore, we declare our position in support of Iran, its leadership, and its people — and we will act as we see fit in confronting this treacherous American-‘Israeli’ aggression,” Qassem said in a statement sent by Hezbollah’s spokesperson. He also said President Trump’s “threat of aggression” against Iran’s supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei constitutes “an attack on all the peoples of the region.”

    The Iranian-backed militant group has stepped up its symbolic support for Iran in the past few days, including hosting a solidarity event for Iran in Beirut tomorrow.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s complaint Thursday that his son’s wedding was postponed due to a conflict that has killed dozens of Israelis is not landing well.

    Speaking to reporters at the Soroka Medical Center, struck Thursday by Iran, Netanyahu compared the “people’s resilience” of Israelis to that of the British during the Blitz, the Nazi German bombing campaign against British cities during World War II. “We are going through a Blitz,” he said. And he said his “own family has not been spared,” he added.

    “This is the second time my son, Avner, has had to cancel his wedding due to rocket fire and the threat of missiles,” he said. “That is certainly a heavy personal cost for him, for his fiancée, and for our family.

    “What are dead and wounded people, and those who lost everything to the missiles, compared to the personal price of the Netanyahu family?” wrote journalist Aviad Glickman of Israel’s Channel 13 on X.

  • Return to menu

    More than 700 patients were at the Soroka Medical Center when the strike hit Thursday, the facility said. Some 80 people, half of them staff, suffered injuries it called “mild or stress-related.”

    Scores of patients have been discharged or transferred to other hospitals. Around 300 patients remain.

    The hospital is now closed to non-urgent admissions.

  • Trump to make decision on Iran strike within two weeks, White House says

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump says he will make a decision about whether to take action in Iran within the next two weeks, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Thursday.

    In what she called a “message directly” from Trump, Leavitt told reporters: “And I quote, ‘Based on the fact that there’s a substantial chance of negotiations that may or may not take place with Iran in the near future, I will make my decision whether or not to go within the next two weeks.’”

  • Israel claims Iran launched cluster munition

    Return to menu

    Israel’s Home Front Command alleged Thursday that Iran had launched a missile equipped with a cluster warhead toward central Israel.

    Cluster munitions disperse bomblets across a wider area than a single missile strike, to increase damage. They’re typically deployed against troops, vehicle convoys and airfields.

    Some lethal bomblets can settle on the ground without detonating, posing an ongoing danger to civilians as well as military personnel.

  • Return to menu

    Prime Minister Netanyahu on Thursday visited the Soroka Hospital, which was hit in an Iranian strike. He posted a video on X with the health minister and mayor of Be’er-Sheva. “We are hitting with precision the targets of the nuclear and missile programs, and they’re hitting a hospital,” he said.

  • Trump is as unpredictable as ever, even when faced with war

    Return to menu

    Does he want to be a wartime president, or the broker of peace? Can he convince his MAGA base that going to war with Iran isn’t the kind of entanglement he has spent more than a decade warning against?

    Even he doesn’t seem to know yet. “You don’t seriously think I’m going to answer that question?” President Donald Trump said when asked Wednesday if he had decided on U.S. strikes in Iran. “... You know, I may do it. I may not do it.”

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • State Dept. considering ‘all available options’ for U.S. nationals in Israel

    Return to menu

    The State Department said it is considering “all available options” to repatriate U.S. nationals stuck in Israel as the country’s conflict with Iran intensifies and its airports and seaports remain restricted.

    The department said in a statement that it “is always planning for contingencies to assist with private U.S. citizens’ departure from crisis areas” and will provide more information as options become available. It recommended that U.S. nationals take any available safe route out of Israel.

  • Return to menu

    Grand Ayatollah Ali Sistani, Iraq’s top Shiite authority, warned in a statement Thursday that targeting Iran’s senior religious or political leadership would have “extremely grave consequences for the situation across the entire region,” in an apparent reference to President Donald Trump saying that he would not assassinate Iran’s supreme leader — for now. “It may lead to complete loss of control and widespread chaos, further worsen the suffering of people and severely harm the interests of all parties involved,” he said. Following an Iranian strike that hit a hospital in southern Israel on Thursday, Israeli Defense Minister Israel Katz said Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, “can no longer be allowed to exist.”

  • Map: Where Israeli strikes have hit Iran

    Return to menu

    Airstrikes continued for a seventh day Thursday amid the most intense faceoff in the history of the Israel-Iran conflict. Israel said it struck targets across Iran in the past 24 hours, including around the capital, Tehran, and several nuclear sites. Israeli officials said they would intensify strikes on Tehran after a key hospital in southern Israel was hit in an Iranian missile attack.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Russia warns Israel against hitting Iran’s nuclear facilities

    Return to menu

    Russia’s Foreign Ministry issued a stern warning to Israel against raids on Iran’s nuclear facilities amid mistaken reports that the country’s only functioning nuclear plant was attacked.

    The Bushehr nuclear power plant on the Persian Gulf is partly operated by Russian technicians. After a news report Thursday cited Israel as saying the site was attacked, an Israeli military official later told reporters at a briefing that “it was a mistake” to include Bushehr in the list of sites attacked.

  • We asked 1,000 Americans if they support U.S. strikes on Iran. This is what they said.

    Return to menu

    What do Americans think about the possibility of launching U.S. airstrikes against Iran, which President Donald Trump threatened this week unless the country dismantles its nuclear program? The Washington Post texted more than 1,000 people on Wednesday to ask.

    The poll finds Americans opposing U.S. airstrikes against Iran by a 20 percentage-point margin — 45 percent to 25 percent — with a sizable 30 percent saying they are unsure.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military estimates it has destroyed two-thirds of Iran’s missile launchers over the first seven days of the conflict, according to a military official speaking on the condition of anonymity to brief reporters on military operations. Israel estimates there to be “more than 100” launchers left in Iran’s arsenal, the official said, without citing evidence for the estimate, which could not be independently verified.

  • Soroka Hospital is among largest in Israel

    Return to menu

    Soroka Medical Center, which was hit Thursday during an Iranian missile barrage, is among the largest hospitals in Israel.

  • The scene at Soroka Medical Center, hit in strike

    Return to menu

    Reporting from Soroka Medical Center

    BEER SHEVA, Israel — Israel’s Soroka Medical Center was hit in an Iranian attack, the medical center and Israeli officials said Thursday, which caused a fire to break out and damage across the hospital.

    Israeli military engineers were assessing the extent of the damage to one of the country’s largest hospital facilities, which evacuated patients following the attack. “We’ve closed the medical center except for emergency care,” Shlomi Codish, the hospital’s director, told reporters.

  • These Iran nuclear sites are in Israel’s crosshairs as U.S. weighs strikes

    Return to menu

    Preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons has been the primary goal of U.S. and Israeli policy toward Iran for decades. The Iranian nuclear program has existed in some form since the 1950s, when Iran was ruled by a U.S.-backed monarchy and Washington supported the development of an Iranian civil nuclear sector. On Friday, Israel launched a wave of strikes on Iran, including on its nuclear facilities. As the United States weighs whether to join Israeli efforts to take out Iran’s nuclear program, here’s what we know about the sites that Israel has attacked so far, why they are so difficult to destroy and what nuclear hazards the strikes could pose.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • European foreign ministers plan to meet with Iranian counterpart Friday, officials say

    Return to menu

    BRUSSELS — European foreign ministers will hold talks with their Iranian counterpart on Friday in Geneva, a meeting being coordinated with Washington, two officials familiar with the planning said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive plans.

    Foreign ministers of Germany, France and Britain will meet with E.U. foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas and then hold talks with Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, the officials said.

  • What is the Massive Ordnance Penetrator, the U.S. bunker-busting bomb?

    Return to menu

    In the event the United States enters the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran, a likely focus will be on degrading or destroying Tehran’s underground facilities that enrich nuclear material.

    That task would most likely fall to a small number of Air Force strategic bombers that are capable of delivering 30,000-pound precision-guided bombs designed to destroy subterranean targets. This bomb, the GBU-57, is better known as a “bunker buster” or the Massive Ordnance Penetrator.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Video: Israeli rescue workers inspect missile strike site in Ramat Gan

    Return to menu

  • Putin and Xi say Israeli attacks violate international law

    Return to menu

    Russian President Vladimir Putin spoke with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, about the situation in the Middle East and condemned Israeli attacks on Iran, a top Russian official said Thursday.

  • Return to menu

    Closing the Strait of Hormuz is one option Iran is considering, Behnam Saeedi, a member of Iran’s parliamentary National Security committee, told the semiofficial Mehr news agency Thursday. Some 20 percent of oil traded globally passes through the strait, which connects the Persian Gulf with the Gulf of Oman and Arabian Sea.

  • U.N. nuclear watchdog says no radiological effect after Khondab strike

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — The United Nations nuclear watchdog said Thursday there were no radiological effects after Iran’s Khondab heavy water research reactor was hit.

    The Israeli military said its warplanes hit the inactive nuclear reactor in Arak overnight and targeted its “component intended for plutonium production, in order to prevent the reactor from being restored and used for nuclear weapons development.”

  • Near-total internet blackout in Iran, NetBlocks says

    Return to menu

    Iran’s near-total internet blackout extended beyond 20 hours on Thursday, according to NetBlocks, which monitors internet access worldwide.

    The disruption began Wednesday evening, and internet traffic monitoring into the afternoon Thursday showed “no sign of restoration,” NetBlocks said in a statement.

  • Return to menu

    Russian President Vladimir Putin said he is in contact with Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu about the conflict between Israel and Iran and called for a solution that protects the interests of both sides. Speaking to journalists Wednesday at the Saint Petersburg Economic Forum, Putin acknowledged it was a “delicate issue” but said he believes “such a solution can be found.”

  • Photos: Iran strikes Ramat Gan, a business district near Tel Aviv

    Return to menu

    Photos from Ramat Gan, a business district in the Tel Aviv area, show a heavily damaged residential building on Thursday morning after the latest round of missile strikes from Iran.

  • With ally Iran under attack, Hezbollah stays out of the fray for now

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — Hezbollah is holding its fire during Iran’s conflict with Israel as it faces domestic pressure not to drag a fragile Lebanon into war and bets the violence does not yet threaten the survival of its longtime patron, diplomats and people close to the group said.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • Return to menu

    Ramat Gan, a city near Tel Aviv in Israel’s Dan area, was hit in a missile strike, mayor Carmel Shama-Hacohen said on Facebook. The strike hit an area with residential and commercial buildings, marking the third time in the current conflict with Iran that the city was affected, he said. Visuals showed an apartment building was hit.

  • Return to menu

    Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday morning on X that Israel will “exact the full price” from Iran for its missile attack that hit the Soroka Medical Center in southern Israel.

  • Hospital in southern Israel hit during missile barrage

    Return to menu

    Soroka Medical Center in Beersheba, Israel, was directly hit during a missile barrage early Thursday, the hospital and the Israel Defense Forces said. A spokesperson for the hospital said on X that there was “extensive damage” and that it was carrying out an assessment, including of casualties.

    Israel’s Fire and Rescue Authority said a direct hit on the medical facility caused a fire. The hospital is the largest in southern Israel, according to the Israel Defense Forces.

  • Return to menu

    Defense Minister Israel Katz said Wednesday in a statement that he has instructed the Israeli military to “intensify strikes against strategic targets in Iran and government sites in Tehran,” in retaliation for the hospital attack. Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, will be held accountable for the attack, Katz added. President Donald Trump said this week he knows Khamenei’s location but is not looking to assassinate him for now.

  • Trump gave Iran an ultimatum but has made no final decision on war

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump delivered an “ultimate ultimatum” to Iranian leaders to dismantle their nuclear program, he told reporters on Wednesday. But he said he has not made a final decision about whether to strike Iran and draw Washington into a new conflict in the Middle East.

    Trump said “the next week is going to be big” and maintained that Iranian officials are eager to negotiate, but he explained that after Iranians reached out to him, he warned them that “it’s very late to be talking.”
